column257: SPHERE conducts fundamental and applied research concerning the adaptation of aquatic and terrestrial organisms to their environment and the effects of environmental contamination on the health status of organisms, populations and communities. Within this framework three lines of research can be distinguished. The first line is work concerning the bioavailability and accumulation of environmental contaminants, the second line concerns the mode of action and mechanisms of toxicity and the third line aims to relate effects at different levels of functional organisation. The research uses in vitro as well as in vivo models and focuses on molecular and cellular aspects (gene expression, protein synthesis, cellular functions) as well as organismal aspects (bioavailability, homeostasis and adaptation). The studies have different applications in environmental toxicology with special emphasis on environmental diagnostics and the development and evaluation of environmental quality criteria (molecular and cellular markers, exposure and effects models, toxicity evaluation and risk assessment).

column257: CAPTURE (www.capture-resources.be) is a multidisciplinary research platform that focuses on resource recovery from water, CO2 and plastic. An important objective of the CAPTURE initiative is to translate research into societal stakeholders such as businesses, governments and citizens. Currently 20 professors are involved. A dedicated building, located on the easily accessible new technology park Eiland Zwijnaarde, south of Ghent is the focal point of the platform. This building contains a large technology hall (800 m2; 2 floors) for larger experimental setups as well as 2 floors of incubator space for start-ups.

column257: ELI pioneers fundamental and applied research to understand the basic processes of the Earth & Life system. The Institute designs research-based solutions at different scales to meet the major challenges associated with the sustainable development of the Earth and Life System. ELI promotes and stimulates interdisciplinary interactions between scientists of complementary expertise that aims to understand the processes controlling the dynamics of the Earth and Life systems at spatial scales deriving from molecules to organisms populations up to global cycles, and time scales from sub-daily to millions of years; to identify drivers of change through quantitative monitoring of indicators and application of hierarchical models; and to innovate in technical management and regulation, both in natural and industrial processes and systems, including renewable resource development and agricultural policy.

column257: ACODEV est la fédération francophone et germanophone des associations de coopération au développement. column233: Water projects are the main focus of my organisation
column257:
The International Hydrological Programme (IHP) is the only intergovernmental programme of the UN system devoted to water research, water resources management, and education and capacity building. Since its inception in 1975, IHP has evolved from an internationally coordinated hydrological research programme into an encompassing, holistic programme to facilitate education and capacity building, and enhance water resources management and governance.

IHP facilitates an interdisciplinary and integrated approach to watershed and aquifer management, which incorporates the social dimension of water resources, and promotes and develops international research in hydrological and freshwater sciences. UNESCO's International Hydrological Programme, founded in 1975 and implemented in six-year programmatic time intervals or phases, is entering its eighth phase to be implemented during the period 2014-2021.

column257: “Ingenieurs zonder Grenzen” started in 1992 on the initiative of the “Koninklijke Vlaamse Ingenieurs Vereniging” (KVIV, now ie-net). The aim is to use the technical know-how of engineers for humanitarian aid in developing countries. IzG supports non-commercial projects in the fields of water, energy, agriculture, construction and the environment in cooperation with other organizations (eg municipalities, non-profit organizations, NGOs, 4th pillar initiatives, etc.). The intervention is free of charge, the employees are volunteers. After acceptance of a project, engineers from IzG work out a technical study (feasibility, determination of needs and possible solutions, ...) A project usually does not stop at "the study": in many cases IzG sends one or more engineers to the country of implementation for 1 to 3 weeks. From the perspective of IZG, development cooperation is to support the local population in the development of their self-sufficiency, in collaboration with the organizations present locally. The development of sustainable solutions, with ownership of the local population, must be promoted as much as possible.
